Hi all,

> Yes, this reviewer attitude bothers me too... There should be a place for
> qualitative exploration. I had paper (also physically simulated robots)
> that got similar criticism from a reviewer, "You didn't test any
> hypothesis." ... yes but we got pretty interesting / unprecedented evolved
> behavior out of the robots!

I hate being the kind of reviewer who seems to bother you but I strongly
disagree with this kind of statement. (disclaimer: I did not review this
paper).

Good science is made with papers on which we can rely, that is papers that
contain results solid enough to makes things go forward. It is not made of
fun "proofs of concept" (which are perfectly fun to watch on youtube).

Overall, as a reviewer, I judge a paper by "how much I learned by reading
this paper".

Testing an hypothesis is a very good way to teach me something: after
reading your paper, I will know whether hypothesis XX is true or false. In
my future work, I can assume that "we know that XX is true, therefore it
is relevant to do ZZ".

Benchmarks are another approach: I will know whether method XX performs
better than methods YY on this test. There are meaningless benchmarks and
I don't learn anything with them, but if your benchmark is relevant, I
will have learned something.

More generally, measures are one of the best tools to build solid
knowledge and there are many other things to measure than performance. For
instance, I'm finishing a paper in which we introduce a measure of
regularity and show how generative encodings generate different level of
regularity. Once we have a measure, we can test hypothesis and use
statistics to verify our claims.

Last, proving that an intuition is wrong is also an interesting way to
teach me something. Joel & Ken's novelty search is a good example: by
showing that objective-based search can easily be outperformed by a simple
novelty-based algorithm, this idea clearly made me think. But this paper
showed something with statistics and arguments. We don't really know
whether novelty search is a better optimization algorithm, but the paper
taught me something with solid arguments -- and this is what matters.

So, if you show that your complex system can generate "pretty interesting
/ unprecedented behaviors", chances are high that I will not learn any
solid knowledge. If you show me that one element of system is the key of
you success, then I may learn something. But this is almost testing an
hypothesis "we test test whether XX is mandatory to obtain YY". If you
show me that this element is a key to change property XX to YY and that it
is the same for a few equivalent systems, then we are starting to build
knowledge that we can use in future work. Showing this will probably
require measuring many things, but benchmarks per se are not mandatory;
creating solid foundations for our field is mandatory.

In summary, we need papers that create a solid foundation of facts.
Hypothesis, measures and statistics are the basic tools for this.
Showcasing ideas is rarely an efficient method (I'm sure we can find a few
counter-examples). Even K. Sims paper does not teach much, but remember
that its most famous paper was published in SIGGRAPH, a computer graphics
conference in which your goal is to show nice pictures and movie. I've
seen too many papers that describe how "cool" a complex system is, without
teaching us anything new. And I've seen too many students starting a new
project in our field without any solid literature to rely on. They can
find many ideas in the literature. They can have their own "cooler" ideas.
But, at the end, they spend their whole Ph.D. writing a complex
evolutionary system that does to teach anything to anybody.


Best regards,
-- JBM
